stem: The nurse is caring for a client with a T6 spinal cord injury. Review the client's electronic health record and determine the priority nursing interventions. Drag the interventions into the order in which they should be performed. Use all options.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct: The correct order of interventions is: 1. Elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees to decrease cerebral blood pressure. 2. Assess for bladder distention as this is the most common cause of autonomic dysreflexia. 3. Administer hydralazine 10 mg IV push as ordered to reduce blood pressure. 4. Monitor blood pressure every 5 minutes to evaluate the effectiveness of the medication and detect any adverse effects.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion:
S: Stop what you are doing.
I: Investigate the cause.
T: Take blood pressure.
U: Upright position.
P: PRN medication if ordered/needed.

rationale.incorrect: Incorrect ordering can result from not prioritizing interventions based on the severity and immediacy of the client's condition. Failure to recognize the urgency of lowering the blood pressure and identifying the cause of the autonomic dysreflexia can lead to poor outcomes. Delaying blood pressure reduction and not promptly addressing the underlying cause prolongs the hypertensive crisis, increasing the risk of stroke, seizure, or myocardial infarction.

questionTrap.trap: Students may prioritize medications over assessment and positioning, overlooking the initial non-pharmacological interventions that are crucial for stabilizing the patient.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and basic interventions like positioning before resorting to medication. Consider the underlying pathophysiology to guide your decision-making process.

clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention.
Always elevate the head of the bed first to lower blood pressure.
Bladder distention and fecal impaction are the most common triggers.

itemContext.sbar:
S: Mr. Smith, age 45, T6 spinal cord injury, admitted three days ago. He is reporting a severe headache and blurred vision. BP is 210/110 mmHg and heart rate is 50 bpm. He's flushed and diaphoretic above the level of the injury.
B: Patient sustained a T6 spinal cord injury in a motor vehicle accident one week ago. No prior history of hypertension. Bowel program initiated yesterday.
A: Possible autonomic dysreflexia. BP is critically elevated. Heart rate is bradycardic. He is reporting severe headache and blurred vision. Assess for bladder distention and fecal impaction. Administer ordered PRN antihypertensive medication.
R: I recommend immediate intervention to address the elevated blood pressure and identify the cause of the autonomic dysreflexia. 07:00: Called MD and received new orders. 07:05: Begin implementing orders.
